hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the linked list. Each node has a value and a pointer to the next node. Familiarize yourself with how to traverse a linked list.
Consider how you can identify the values in the linked list that are also present in the `nums` array. A good approach is to use a set for quick lookups.
Think about how to define 'connected components'. Two values are connected if they appear consecutively in the linked list. You might want to keep track of the previous node's value as you traverse.
As you traverse the linked list, maintain a counter for the number of connected components. Increment this counter when you find the first value in `nums` after a non-connected value.
Make sure to handle the case where the linked list starts with a value in `nums`. This can affect how you count your components.
When counting components, remember to check both the current and the next node. If both are in `nums`, they form part of the same component.
Consider edge cases, such as when `nums` contains only one element or when all elements in `nums` are consecutive in the linked list.
You can use a boolean flag to indicate whether you are currently in a connected component. Reset this flag when you encounter a value not in `nums`.

Ensure that your solution runs efficiently, ideally in O(n) time complexity, where n is the number of nodes in the linked list. Think about how you can achieve this with a single pass through the list.
Finally, remember to return the count of connected components you have tracked. Make sure your return statement is placed correctly after you finish traversing the linked list.

questionNotes: The linked list contains unique integer values.
The array `nums` is a subset of the linked list values and also contains unique integers.
Two values are connected if they appear consecutively in the linked list.
The output should be the number of connected components found in `nums`.
